column2: I was drying my hair and ironing my shirt! Can you come here for a sec? I need your help.
column3: What is it? Why are all these clothes on the bed?
column4: I don ’ t know what to wear! Ok, give me your opinion. Do you like the way this looks? The striped short sleeved shirt with this checkered sweater and my lucky sandals. I like the cut and hemline of these shorts so I think I ’ ll wear these as well.
column5: Are you joking? What am I going to do with you? We are going to a dinner party not the beach! Wear the shirt with the silk tie I bought you and these corduroy pants. It ’ s chilly outside so you can wear this coat.
column6: Thanks honey! You have such great fashion sense. Now, what am I going to do with my hair?

column1: Ben, what are you doing?
column2: Well, I would say that I ’ m just drifting - - here, in the pool.
column3: Why?
column4: Well, it ’ s very comfortable just to drift here.
column5: Have you thought about graduate school?
column6: No.
column7: Would you mind telling me then — what were those four years of college for? What was the point of all that hard work?
column8: You got me.
column9: Now listen, Ben. Look, I think it ’ s a very good thing that a young man — after he ’ s done some very good work — should have a chance to relax and enjoy himself, and lie around, and drink beer and so on. But after a few weeks I believe that person should want to take some stock in himself and his situation and start to think about getting off his ass.

column1: There are so many people that the tickets are all sold out!
column2: Luckily we got the last two.
column3: Look, Danny. The Four Great Inventions!
column4: Gunpowder, compass, the paper making, and the printing.
column5: I really admire those who made such great inventions!
column6: May, I don't see why they are great. They are just simple things.
column7: They look simple today. But they were milestones in their times.
column8: Milestones? May, you must be kidding.
column9: Just think Bill Gates, those inventions are as important as the windows system.
column10: Well, I suppose the ancient inventors made a lot of money out of them.
column11: No, quite the contrary.
column12: Why? Didn't you say that they were milestones?
column13: Yes, but they went to the public without any patent protection.
column14: Well, their inventors were not as clever as Bill Gates.

column1: Excuse me, what's the actual flying time from here to Zurich?
column2: It's about 12 hours.
column3: Can you tell me when we are arriving?
column4: Let me see... at 6:15 am local time tomorrow.
column5: Gotcha.
column6: And that will be 10:15 pm Tokyo time.

column1: Wedding rings!
column2: Oh, no...
column3: Aren't they cool? I like the settings.
column4: Jen, is there someone you're not telling me about?
column5: No. I just like looking at wedding rings, OK?
column6: Women are such dreamers.
column7: These are specially designed for the year 2000!

column1: My, it looks too queer!
column2: Yes, it is a queer drug, a tonic only available in China. Many ancient Chinese medicine journals have recorded that it can cure such ailments as night sweat, pain at loins and knees and anaemia. It has no side effect.
column3: Great! Will you please tell me how to take it?
column4: Yes, madam. Fill 3 or 5 pieces of Cordyceps into a cleaned and chopped open duck's head and cook with the whole duck. Or stew Cordyceps with chicken.
column5: That sounds very interesting!
column6: Please don't eat turnip and garlic when taking this medicine.
column7: Thank you very much.

column1: I need a room for a few days.
column2: That won't be a problem. Could you please tell me your name?
column3: John Sandals. That's S A N D A L S.
column4: Sir, I'm Michelle, and I run the front desk. Please tell me the days you'll be here.
column5: I'll be there in April Friday through Monday, the 14th through the 17th.
column6: We recently changed many things here, sir, including our prices. Do you mind, sir?
column7: Possibly. What's the actual price?
column8: The price will be $ 308 a night.
column9: $ 308! That's not bad.
column10: Very good. Now, Mr. Sandals, about the room, smoking or nonsmoking?
column11: Nonsmoking, definitely!
column12: Most of our clients prefer nonsmoking. Now, does a queen sound okay?
column13: Yes, that'll be just fine.
column14: One more second, sir. Your reservation is now verified, so all I need is your phone number.
column16: Let me repeat that 626-555-1739. Okay, sir, we look forward to seeing you in April!

column1: Have you ever thought about Tom ’ s attitude?
column2: I ’ Ve cut it up and come to the conclusion that hi is actually sick of Jenny ’ s brother. But he likes Jenny. She is a big apple in his eye.
column3: Love me, love my dog. He ’ s a sensible kind man.
column4: That ’ s why many people look up to him.

column1: Do you like traveling?
column2: Yes, I've just come back from Scotland.
column3: Where did you visit?
column4: I only had time to visit Edinburgh.
column5: How did you like it?
column6: It's fantastic.
column7: Why did you go there?
column8: I went there on business.
column9: And do you have friends there?
column10: Yes, a lot of friends.
column11: You must have enjoyed yourself.
column12: Yes, and I look many pictures.

column1: Happy New Year!
column2: Thank you! The same to you.
column3: Have you got any plans?
column4: I've been invited over to a friend's. And you?
column5: My roommate's having a party.

column1: Eat some more.
column2: No, thanks. I'm on a diet.

column1: What can I do for you?
column2: Would you recommend some materials on the World War Two?
column3: Have you found a particular item from the card catalogue?
column4: Yes, but I don't think they are enough for me.
column5: Oh, maybe you can find something from the New York Times, or the Washington Post during that period.
column6: That's a good idea. Thanks a lot.
column7: You are welcome.

column1: Are we going to have dinner tonight?
column2: What are you planning on making?
column3: I'm not cooking dinner.
column4: The only way you're eating tonight is if you cook.
column5: I'm not sure what to cook for dinner.
column6: I don't know. What do you want to eat?
column7: I have a taste for some chicken and potatoes.
column8: That sounds delicious.
column9: So are you planning on cooking it?
column10: I already told you that I'm not cooking tonight.
column11: I'll cook dinner.
column12: I already know. Start cooking.

column1: Open you suitcase, please.
column2: OK.Here you are.
column3: Do you have anything to declare?
column4: No, I don't.
column5: Any cigarette, liquor?
column6: Yes, I have two cartons of cigarettes, one bottle of whisky.
column7: What's this white powder? Are they drugs?
column8: No, this is the medicine for the stomach.
column9: May I open one of these? Let me taste it.
column10: Yes, sir.Go ahead.Here you are.

column1: Good morning. Can I help you?
column2: Good morning. I'd like to make a reservation to Guangzhou for August 2.
column3: Just a moment, please. I'm sorry, sir. There is no ticket available on that day. But we have flights for Guangzhou the next day.
column4: May I inquire about the departure time?
column5: A 9:12 flight in the morning and a 14:00 flight in the afternoon.
column6: When will the plane reach for the morning flight?
column8: OK. I'd like to book a ticket for this one.
column9: All right, sir. Please reconfirm your ticket no later than 12 o'clock two days before the flight ; otherwise, your reservation will automatically be cancelled.

column1: Hi Paul. How are you, friend.
column2: Not good. My cousin is driving me up the wall.
column3: How so?
column4: He stays up untill all hours of the night, and he never lifts a finger to help.
column5: Have you talk to him about it?
column6: Not yet, but I have to soon. He's eating me out of house and home. I caught him reading the fridge again last night
column7: Ahahah, Maybe that will help you lose weight.
column8: This is no laughing matter, Nick.
column9: Sorry Paul. I couldn't help it. So why doesn't he give you a hand?
column10: He watch the tob too much. Now really I don't know. But I can't handle this much longer.
column11: Well, talk to him, and let me know what happens, OK?

column1: What kind of movies do you like, Sue?
column2: I like all kinds of stuff. I admit I love romance.
column3: Just like my wife. So, what ’ s your favorite movie?
column4: You mean my favorite movie of all time? I guess I ’ d have to say “ pretty woman ”.
column5: Yeah, my wife likes that one, too. Personally, I prefer action movies.

column1: What's your new girlfriend like?
column2: Katherine? Well, she's good at languages.
column3: Does she know how to speak Spanish?
column4: She knows how to speak Spanish and Japanese.
column5: Wow!!!
column6: And she's good at sports, too. She knows how to play tennis and basketball.
column7: That's terrific!
column8: But there's one thing she's not good at.
column9: What's that?
column10: She's not good at remembering things. We have a date, and she's an hour late!!

column1: Have you been coming to this Laundromat long?
column2: I have been washing clothes here since a few years ago.
column3: Why is that?
column4: It doesn't cost me as much to wash here.
column5: I've just started doing my clothes here.
column6: Why are you washing your clothes here now?
column7: My washing machine broke down.
column8: You should just pay someone to fix it.
column9: It's too expensive to get it fixed.
column10: So you're just going to wash here?
column11: Yeah, I think that's what I'm going to have to do.
column12: It costs less to wash here.

column1: What do you want for your birthday from your parents?
column2: I don't know. Maybe a pair of new shoes.
column3: Why don't you ask them to buy you a PC? You will soon use it at college.
column4: That's a dandy idea. Thank you for reminding me.

column1: So do you think you can get to the office alone?
column2: Sure, I ’ ll catch the train. If I can ’ t catch the train, I ’ ll get a taxi.
column3: Do you think the taxi driver will understand you?
column4: If he doesn ’ t understand me, I ’ ll show him the office address on my business card.
column5: Ok but how will we know if you are going to be late?
column6: I ’ ll call you if I ’ m delayed.

column1: I'd like to meet you again sometime.
column2: That would be great. Actually, can I get your phone number, Ella? That's assuming you don't mind if I call you sometime.
column3: Anytime. You can reach me at 5558929.
column4: Ok, got it. I will call you sometime next week.
column5: Fine.
column6: It's time to go. Bye, Ella. Hope to see you soon
column7: Bye, Jason.

column1: Tom, Christmas Day is coming. Merry Christmas to you.
column2: Thank you. And a merry Christmas to you!

column1: There are things that are actually even smaller than atoms.
column2: What are those?
column3: They are the things that make up the atom, such as electrons and protons.
column4: Is there anything that is smaller than electrons and protons?
column5: Of course there is. Things can be divided and broken down into indefinitely small parts if we can.
column6: I really don't want to know about this. Physics gives me a headache.

column1: So, tell me about you new house. How is it different to your old one?
column2: Well, first of all, it ’ s much bigger. It has the same number of rooms, but each room is larger. We also have a larger garden, which our dog loves, of course!
column3: So, it ’ s a three-bedrooms detached house?
column4: Yes. One bedroom is for my wife and I. there ’ s another for our daughter. My wife wants to use the third one as a guest room, but I ’ d like to make it into a study. Our daughter is also keen on making it a study, so that ’ s probably what will happen.
column5: What ’ s the kitchen like? I know both you and your wife like to cook.
column6: That ’ s one of the main reason we chose that particular house. The kitchen and dining room are together. It ’ s really large.
column7: Are the rooms nice and bright?
column8: Yes, they are. That ’ s very important to us. We like to live in a home with plenty of natural light. Each room has large windows.
column9: Do you have a balcony?
column10: No, we don ’ t. We wish we had one. That ’ s the only thing we wanted, but don ’ t have. The area is very nice and the neighbours seem friendly.
column11: You ’ re right on the edge of the city, aren ’ t you? There can ’ t be much noise or traffic there. Is it easy to get into city centre?
column12: It ’ s a very quiet neighbourhood. There ’ s some traffic, but not much. It ’ s not very difficult to get to the city centre, but you must remember to turn left and right at the right places or you ’ ll get lost. So when are you going to drop by?

column1: Our neighbour ’ s tape recorder is so loud that it annoys us to death. I ’ Ve made up my mind to cut the electricity off.
column2: What? That would be to cut off your nose to spite your face.
column3: Then what shall we do?
column4: Call the police.

column1: Guess what came in the mail today?
column2: What?
column3: My acceptance letter to Yale!
column4: Wow! Congratulation! When do classes start?
column5: Freshman orientation is the last week of august, but I want to go two weeks before that to get settled in.
column6: You ’ re so lucky! Do you have to do many things before you leave?
column7: Yes. I ’ ll be very busy! I have to get a visa, buy a plane ticket, and pack my things. But first, I want to register for classes.
column8: When can you do that?
column9: Well, they sent me their prospectus, so I can start looking now. do you want to help me decide which classed to take?
column10: Sure. What can you choose from?
column11: Well, I have to take all the fundamental course, plus a few from my major.
column12: What is your major?
column13: I hope to major in English literature, but the admissions counselor told me that many people change their major many times in their first year, so we ’ ll see.
column14: What are the fundamental course?
column15: In order to graduate, every student must take a certain amount of classes in history, math, English, philosophy, science and art.
column16: Interesting. That ’ s very different from the Chinese education system.
column17: Yes, it is. It ’ s also very different from the British education system.
column19: oh, sure. In British, students don ’ t have to take the foundation course.
column21: maybe because they think they know everything already! ha ha.

column1: I think the biggest environment problem in my country is air pollution.
column2: Yes, I agree. The air here is much more polluted than in my country.
column3: That's because your country is more agricultural and has much less industry.
column4: Yeah, you are right.
column5: We have reduced emission of air pollutants in recent years, but cars are still a major source of them. Factories have become cleaner as stricter environment pollution laws have been introduced.
column6: The problem is now on a truly global scale. I don't believe that any single country can do anything about it.
column7: I think you're right. An international response to this problem is needed.

column1: Did you watch the finale last night? My favorite singer won!
column2: Oh, I love him too. He not only sings well but shows perseverance when he encounters difficulties in the contest.
column3: Yeah, he got booted after his initial performance in the audition, but he did not give up. He then tried at another two auditions.
column4: He had barely survived the third audition and finally got a chance to advance in the contest. Fortunately, in the third audition, he has won popularity among the audience. And that's when I started to notice him.
column5: Me too.
column6: Before he made the top three, I was so nervous. I just fear that he might be knocked out.
column7: Yeah, there're so many excellent candidates out there. Who knows which one will make it to the final?
column8: Absolutely. That's why when he entered the finale, I was so excited.
column9: He really did a great job in the finale, especially in the PK round. He performed so well that the majority of the audience cast their votes for him.
column10: And the host announced that he won it all!

column1: These things are always oooo boring. Heard any gossip? Anybody making the big bucks?
column2: Rich struck it rich in advertising. And he and Cath got married and just had a child.
column3: That's no news. Those two were high school sweethearts anyway.
column4: Teresa Jones got a boob job.
column5: Uh, I can see that. And Erica Falls has lost a lot of weight.
column6: I've got something. You saw Taylor Smith? Looks terrible, doesn't he? I heard he...

column1: Good morning, sir. What can I do for you?
column2: I want to check in.
column3: Have you made a reservation?
column4: No, I want a double room. By the way, is there any discount for children?
column5: Yes, children are half price.
column6: Ok, please have me arrange one.

column1: Overseas operator, may I help you?
column2: Yes. I would like to place a collect call.
column3: Can you tell me the name and number of the person you want?
column4: Terry and his number is 4562325 8.
column5: Please wait a moment. It Will take a few seconds to get through.

column1: Excuse me. I'd like to check out, please.
column2: Of course, sir. Did you have anything from the minibar?
column3: No.
column4: Ok, the total would be $ 367 and 65 cents.How would you pay?
column5: By American express, if that's ok.
column6: Of course, sir. Will you need taxi?
column7: That's ok. I'm expecting a lift from my friend.

column1: Next please! Hello sir, may I see your passport please?
column2: Yes, here you go.
column3: Will you be checking any bags today.
column4: Yes, I ’ d like to check three pieces.
column5: I ’ m sorry, sir. Airline policy allows only two pieces of checked luggage, at twenty kilograms each, plus one piece of carry-on luggage. I will have to charge you extra for the additional suitcase.
column6: What? Why! I am taking an intercontinental flight! I ’ m flying sixteen thousand CMS! How am I supposed to only take two, twenty kilo bags? That ’ absurd!
column7: I am sorry, sir, there ’ s nothing I can do. You cannot board the flight with that large bag either.Carry - on bags must fit in the over-head compartment or under your seat. That bag is clearly too big.
column8: Now I see. You charge next to nothing for an international ticket, but when it comes to charging for any other small thing, you charge an arm and a leg! So tell me, miss, how much will I have to pay for all of this.
column9: Let ’ s see... six hundred and twenty-five US dollars.
column10: That ’ s more than my round-trip ticket!

column1: What did you say?
column2: I said it ’ s a lovely day. Why don't we go for a walk?
column3: Well, I feel a little tired.
column4: Come on! Rest breads rust.
column5: Then can you wait a few minutes? I want to finish writing this letter.
column6: I hope it won't be too long. It would be a shame not to take advantage of such lovely weather.
column7: It won't be long. No more than ten minutes. Why don't you go ahead and I'll meet you in the park?
column8: OK! See you later!

column1: What a pin-up she is!
column2: Can you imagine she's over forty?
column3: That's incredible! She has such a sharp figure.
column4: Absolutely.She' s a teacher of aerobics.

column1: I will have sole then.
column2: All right, how about the other guests.
column3: The rest of us will have this today's special, please.
column4: Ok.
column5: I am sorry but I ordered sole not the same as the others. Will you change it?
column6: I'm afraid we have no more sole.
column7: Then I'll have the pork cutlet instead.
column8: Certainly, just a moment, sir.

column1: Where do you wish me to take you, sir?
column2: Please take us to Harvard University. By the way, is it far from here?
column3: It takes about half an hour to get there.
column4: ( Get here ) Here we are, sir.
column5: How much do I owe you?
column6: It ’ s 35 dollars on the meter.
column7: Here ’ s 50 dollars. Keep the change.
column8: Thank you. Have a nice day.

column1: Hey, Zina. You're here early today.
column2: Yeah, I'm going to be making phone calls all day. What a blast.
column3: I just wanted to say thanks for putting us on the map so fast. I appreciate it.
column4: Save it, Vince. After I put my first million in the bank, I'll say you're welcome.
column5: Fair enough.Keep up the good work.

column1: My son is alway complaining that I dump on him. He was very rude and told me to mind my own business. I cannot put up with that.
column2: What does his dad say?
column3: John is a peacemaker. He simply doesn ’ t bother. He says he should give him a free hand.

column1: Good evening, sir. What's your pleasure?
column2: Give me a shot of whisky and soda.
column3: With or without ice, sir?
column4: Certainly without ice. Ice will spoil the taste.
column5: Would you like to say' when', please, sir. ( Pouring soda )
column6: Whoa, when.
column7: Enjoy your drink, sir.

column1: Last weekend I didn't want to go out either, so I stayed at home and played video games by myself. It was really fun!
column2: Oh yeah, that sounds pretty cool, I guess...
column3: Yeah, I'm really into video games. In fact, all my friends are on the Internet. I've never met any of them in the real world.
column4: Oh really... well you must be very popular on the Internet. But it's true that it's nice to do some things in the comfort of your own home.

column1: I would like high speed internet installed in my house.
column2: You have to make an appointment before we can come out and install it.
column3: I'd like to make an appointment right now.
column4: What day are you available?
column5: I would like to have it done this Friday.
column6: Three o'clock is the only time we can come in.
column7: Is it possible for someone to come a little earlier?
column8: I'm sorry, but that's our only available time.
column9: How about Saturday?
column10: We're completely open on Saturday.
column11: Can you come over at 11
column12: That'll be fine.

column1: Next, please. Where to, sir?
column2: A one-way ticket to Chicago, please.
column3: How many did you say, sir?
column4: One adult, please.
column5: That will be six dollars. Out of ten-seven, eight, nine, ten. Thank you.

column1: I heard there is a big yard sale at weeks this saturday morning, i will go there to see if there is some nice clothes, do you want to go with me?
column2: Well, i want to go to the university flea market, they got times of books, DVDs, and a lot of nice clothing, too.
column3: How about we go to the yard sale first and then to the university flea market?
column4: Good idea, let's shop to we drop!

column1: How's the weather today?
column2: It's cloudy.
column3: Is it going to rain today?
column4: I doubt it.
column5: But I heard it might rain.

column1: It is so quiet here. I like the place.
column2: Me too.
column3: I can't stand the loud noise in the city.
column4: Yes, sometimes I can hardly get asleep at night.
column5: I hope I can stay here longer.
column6: When will your vacation end?
column7: The day after tomorrow.
column8: You will go back tomorrow, right?
column9: Yes, you are right.

column1: Recently I have been getting headache and my eyes don't seems to see focus properly.
column2: When did you last time have your eyes checked?
column3: Two years ago. At that time I had no problems.Now I can ’ t even make out something ten meters away.
column4: Come over here. I will test your eyes. First cover your left eye like this, and when I point, please read the chart from the top, and go as far as you can, telling me which way the “ E ” points.
column5: All right.
column6: Good.Now the other eye.
column7: Well, this one is worse.
column8: Never mind, just read as far as you can.
column9: I can only read the first three lines.

column1: I have a stomachache.
column2: Well, you'd better lie down now. You need a good rest.
column3: All right. I'll do that.

column1: I wish our competition will quit poaching our people, when Susan resigned last week to work for the Sunburst, she was our fourth employee to leave us for them.
column2: Have you ever considered that perhaps we have a morale problem among our employees? If everyone is discontent with their work, of course they won't stick arround.
column3: Well, those do leave will soon find out the grass isn't as green on the other side of sense as they thought it was, I know Sunburst is suffering from inbreeding.
column4: Inbreeding is a big drawback from snitching most of their employers from one or two companies.
column5: With Susan leaving, we should probably look to someone new on board.
column6: Our human resource department is working on it, it's not easy to recruit new employees every few month, it's hard to find qualified people.
column7: Maybe we should start shopping around the competitors people.

column1: So your mom can stop nagging you now.
column2: Trust me. She'll keep nagging. She thinks something will go wrong.
column3: Don't tell me she's been listening to the fortune-teller again.
column4: You guessed it. She says we have to get married on January 2nd, or we'll have bad luck.
column5: The day we choose to get married could never be an unlucky day.
column6: My mom just wants everything to be perfect for us.

column1: Good morning, may I help you?
column2: We'd like to take a tour to Florence.
column3: That's a beautiful city. When do you want to go there?
column4: We have got a 2 weeks' vocation and we plan to leave on Thursday.
column5: Then please have a look at the table, there are so many plans.

column1: Do you know anything about Dr. Miller's classes?
column2: Yes. Are you in his class?
column3: I'm thinking of taking his class next semester.
column4: He really knew his stuff, but he graded hard. Would that be OK?
column5: Yes, I really need someone who is really good.
column6: I didn't find it overwhelming to earn a good grade if you work at it. Can you do that?
column7: Maybe, but I'm not sure.
column8: Man, this guy was so funny when he was teaching. I like that, don't you?
column9: No, that stuff isn't important to me.
column10: Did you know that he is a fairly new teacher and very current in his field?
column11: I don't care about any of that.
column12: We all are looking for different things in an instructor. I hope I've helped you.

column1: This is the menu. What would you like to have?
column2: I don't know what to have. If you don't mind, I'll just leave the choice to you.
column3: With pleasure, sir. May I suggest Steamed stuffed buns and deep-fried twisted dough sticks? They are popular breakfast among Chinese people.
column4: OK. Anything to drink?
column5: Yes, sir. We usually serve soya-bean milk and jellied beancurd. Which one do you prefer, sir? A
column6: I'll try the soya-bean milk this time.
column7: So, that's steamed stuffed buns and deep-fried twisted dough sticks, and a Soya-bean milk.
column8: That's right.
column9: Thank you, sir. Just a moment, please.

column1: Hey Jimmy. Let's go workout later today.
column2: Sure. What time do you want to go?
column3: How about at 3:30?
column4: That sounds good. Today we work on Legs and forearm.
column5: Hey. I just played basketball earlier, so my legs are a little sore. Let's work out on arms and stomach today.
column6: I'm on a weekly schedule. You're messing everything up.
column7: C'mon. We're only switching two days. You can do legs on Friday.
column8: Aright. I'll meet you at the gym at 3:30 then.

column1: Going to the gym tonight, Mary?
column2: Yes, Sally. I want to do some sit-ups and perhaps get in a game of singsong.
column3: That sounds like fun. Would you mind some company?
column4: I'd love it. Working out is more fun with a friend.
column5: I'll get my things and meet you there.
column6: Good. If you happen to see Jim and Bob on the way see if they would like a game of singsong.

column1: Too... your face is really oily... perfect!
column2: Why? Are you planning to stir-fry my face?
column3: Nope. I'm going to tell your fortune. So... the oilier, the better.
column4: You've gone bonkers, Jen.
column5: It's facial paper, and it fits into the rings of my binder! It's magical.
column6: OK. Let's see. Give me a sheet.

column1: Harry is a hen-pecked husband.
column2: No, he isn ’ t.
column3: Then why does he let himself be lead by the nose?
column4: He is afraid of his father-in-law.

column1: Can you deliver it, please?
column2: It depends where you live, sir.
column3: In Camden Town.
column4: Yes, we deliver there. But it costs two pounds fifty.
column5: All right. But I'm only in on Saturday.
column6: Morning or afternoon?
column7: Afternoon, please, if that's possible.

column1: I've brought a little dog for Alice, girls usually like looking after pets.
column2: Thank you, but Alice is only a visitor here. I don't know if she'll keep it.
column3: To tell you the truth, the dog isn't my real reason for coming. I want to ask Alice if she'd like to be my girlfriend.
column4: Really?

column1: Excuse me, I'd like to make a suit of this material.
column2: Well, sir. Can I take your measurements first?
column3: Yes. Should I take off my coat?
column4: That'll be helpful. All right, thank you.
column5: Please make a single-breasted.
column6: No, problem. If you'll wait one moment, I'll make out your receipt.
column7: How much does it cost?
column8: Let me see, with padding and lining cloth, it comes to 357 dollars altogether.
column9: All right. When can I get it?
column10: In two weeks.
column11: Thank you.

column1: Do you have a reservation, sir?
column2: No, I ’ m afraid we don ’ t.
column3: I ’ m sorry the restaurant is full now. You have to wait for about half an hour. Would you like to have a drink at the lounge until there ’ s a table available.
column4: No, thanks, I ’ ll come back later. May I reserve a table for two?
column5: Yes, of course. May I have your name, sir?
column6: Bruce By the way, can we have a table by the window?
column7: we ’ ll try to arrange it, but I can ’ t guarantee sir.
column8: That ’ s fine.
column9: your table's ready, sir? Please step this way.

column1: I hear you are expecting your family.
column2: Yes, my parents, and soon my brother as well.
column3: I didn't know you had a brother.
column4: Oh, yes, he is two years older than me. He lives in New Zealand so I don't see him that often.
column5: Oh, nice. Is he coming on his own or with the family?
column6: His son is coming as well. He wants to go to university here in England so they will visit a few universities while they are here.
column7: Does your brother have just one son?
column8: No, he has two daughters as well. His wife and daughters are visiting her parents. So I won't see them.
column9: I'm sure your parents are looking forward to seeing their grandson.
column10: Oh yes, they are really looking forward to it. They went to New Zealand last year and loved it.
column11: So when are they all coming?
column12: My parents are already here. My brother and nephew are arriving on Monday.

column1: Doris, Helen Mall is having a big sale this weekend. Do you wanna go?
column2: Don't feel like it. I'm broke.
column3: Well, we can still do some window shopping, can we?
column4: Just look around? Nah, that ’ s boring.
column5: I'll go by myself then.

column1: hello. Where are you headed today?
column2: I'm off to Barcelona for a week.
column3: do you have your passport with you?
column4: yes, here you go. I don't need a visa to go to Spain, do I?
column5: fortunately for you, you don't. Next time, if you have any questions about visas, you should try to find out before you get to the airport.
column6: that's good advice.
column7: would you like a window seat or an aisle seat?
column8: are there any seats available by the emergency exits?
column9: let me see here... yes, there's one left.
column10: ok. I'll take that one then.
column11: alright. How many pieces of luggage are you checking in?
column12: I like to travel light so I just have this one.
column13: if that's your only piece of luggage, it is small enough to carry on with you. Would you like to do that so you don't have to wait in luggage reclaim once you arrive?
column14: yes, please. That's a fantastic idea. Which gate do I need to go to?
column15: you're here a bit early, so check the departure screens in the waiting area in about a half hour. Here's your boarding pass. Enjoy your flight!

column1: Could I see the manager please? I have a complaint to make.
column2: Yes, I ’ m the manager here. What can I do for you, Madam?
column3: Did you have the room checked before we move in?
column4: Which room are you in?
column5: 1808. The toilet doesn ’ t work properly. The water doesn ’ t run in the shower.
column6: I ’ m awfully sorry to hear that. ( After checking ) I ’ ll turn to it right away. I do apologize. We ’ ll change your room to 2002.
column7: That ’ s not bad. Thanks for your help.
column8: It ’ s my pleasure, Madam.

column1: Which language do you speak?
column2: Well, I studied French at school, but I ’ Ve forgotten most of it. I learnt some Russian while I was studying there and now I study Spanish in evening classes. Do you speak Japanese at home with your pa
column3: Yes, I do. I ’ m learning Chinese now on the internet.
column4: How do you find studying a language on the internet?
column5: It ’ s not easy, particularly with listening and speaking, because sometimes the connection isn ’ t too good.
column6: I bet you find the character difficult to write!
column7: Actually, many of the characters are the same or very similar in both Chinese and Japanese, so they ’ re easy for me.
column8: So, you can read and write much better than you speak and understand other speakers, right?
column9: Yes. How are the Spanish classes going?
column10: In a way, it ’ s similar to your experience of learning Chinese. Some Spanish words are very similar to English ones. But I need to practise listening to native speakers and saying the words myself.

column1: So, Is this your first time to TAIWAN?
column2: No, I first came here 1995.
column3: Oh, really? And you are from the State, right?
column4: Well, I am from Canada. Actually.
column5: Oh, I am so sorry.
column6: That' ok. That's happens all the time.

column1: What can I do for you, sir?
column2: We'd like to order breakfast for tomorrow morning.
column3: Yes, sir. What would you like?
column4: Orange juice, scrambled eggs, bacon, toast and coffee.
column5: OK, and when shall I bring it here?
column6: About seven thirty.By the way, could you also bring me tomorrow's papers?
column7: Of course, sir.

column1: What are you waiting for? Get on that bus quickly.
column2: But where do I get a ticket?
column3: On the bus. The driver collects the fares. You'll have to take your luggage on board.
column4: Oh, I wish I didn ’ t have so much to carry.

column1: I'm planning on going to the market soon.
column2: What are you buying?
column3: I don't know what we need.
column4: I can check for you, if you'd like.
column5: I'll make a list.
column6: First, we need eggs, milk, and bread.
column7: Okay, do we need any meat?
column8: How about some chicken, ground beef, and some steak?
column9: What else do we need?
column10: Get some snack foods.

column1: Henry, don ’ t get out of doing housework.
column2: It ’ s none of my business.
column3: You mean that is my business.
column4: I don ’ t say that. But it seems to me the housewife should do that.
column5: I ’ m your wife, not a housewife. I have my own work.
column6: Hum...

column1: Jim. I heard you got a promotion!
column2: Yeah, I ’ m going to be running the Walker Avenue Branch.
column3: Congratulations, guy.
column4: Thanks. I appreciate it.

column1: It's Sunday today.
column2: Yes, I know.
column3: I think we should have a house cleaning today. What's your opinion?
column4: Oh, no. We just did it last week.
column5: Come on. What do you want to do? Washing clothes or cleaning the house?
column6: I'd rather wash the clothes.
column7: Okay. Here is the laundry.
column8: Oh, My God! So much!
column9: Don't worry. I'll help you with it later.

column1: That looks like an interesting book.
column2: It is. It ’ s got pictures of interesting building from all over the world, with brief descriptions of how they were build, their purpose, and so on.
column3: There are the pymeids. It ’ s easy to see how they got that name! they don ’ t have smooth sides though.
column4: They don ’ t now, but most of them did originally. There ’ s picture of the pentagon in the United States. It ’ s very distinctive with its five sides.
column5: Look at that cylindrical office building. I ’ Ve never been seen one that shape before.
column6: Yes. Usually only towers are cylindrical in shape.
column7: Tv towers are usually thicker at the bottom than at the top. They ’ re not perfectly cylindrical.
column8: This is the world ’ s largest sports stadium. It ’ s a massive oval.
column9: What sports do they play there?
column10: It says here that it ’ s mainly used for big football matches and athletics meetings.
column11: Is that building a perfect cube?
column12: According to the book, it is. I ’ Ve never seen a building that is a perfect cube. Look at the building. From the air, it looks like a square with a semi-circle attached to each of its four sides. What kind of building is it?
column13: Is says here that it ’ s a war memorial. Now, there ’ s a distinctive structure-the stomium in Brussels. See? It consists of several connected by cylinders. I believe you can go up and down inside it.

column1: How do you like the food?
column2: It tastes really great. Did you cook it?
column3: Yes. I made it this afternoon. Would you like some more?
column4: OK, just a little though. I'm really full.
column5: Oh. Would you like some soup instead?
column6: What kind is it?
column7: Tomato and rice. Have you had that before?
column8: No. This is my first time. How does it taste?
column9: It's good, try it. What do you think?
column10: Wow. It is good. Did you make that also?
column11: Yes.
column12: You're a really good cook.
column13: Thanks, next time I'll make chicken soup for us.
column14: That sounds good. Did you study cooking in school?
column15: No, I learned by myself. I have a good cook book that I read when I have time.

column1: What can I do for you?
column2: I was looking for a book, but I couldn ’ t find it.
column3: Did you check our database to see if it was on the shelf?
column4: I already did.
column5: Is it on the shelf?
column6: I didn ’ t see it.
column7: Apparently somebody took that book out of the library.
column8: Will you ever get another copy?
column9: We will definitely be getting another.
column10: Could you please reserve it for me?
column11: That won ’ t be a problem.
column12: Thanks. I really appreciate that.

column1: Are you really dating with Frank?
column2: Yeah. But in my heart of hearts, I find he ’ s not very much to my liking.
column3: Then why not keep away from him?
column4: The problem is that I just have no one to turn to right now.
column5: That ’ s stupid.

column1: The last thing to be ignored at a Chinese dinner table is to keep modest.
column2: Does that suggest diners avoid speaking much? The same is true in the West.
column3: No, absolutely not! On the contrary, you'll be considered a well-connected, sociable man, if you keep involved in the conversation all the time. But always pay attention to what you say. If the table has a senior guest, say something as upbeat and cheerful as possible. Or maybe, you may give the floor to him and keep listening as if very interested.
column4: You mean, keeping a low profile in the presence of the old? That goes in like with Confucius' preachings, right?
column5: Correct. Show respect for the older people. Conventionally, before the meal starts, the younger members are supposed to address each one of the elderly members of the table one by one. Others are kept in waiting until the most venerable guest proclaim the beginning of the meal and takes the first bite. Toasts also go to these men first before people can toast to each other.
column6: Any other rules to observe in order to keep modest?
column7: Yes, plenty of them. Don't eat fast! People usually keep their dining pace accorded with others. And all the dishes should not be eaten up completely.
column8: Is it because that would give the host the impression that the food was insufficient?
column9: Haha, I'm afraid it's simply because no one wishes to be too noticeable by finishing off the plate.

column1: Good morning madam. What can I get you?
column2: I ’ d like a coffee please.
column3: Certainly madam, what kind of coffee would you like?
column4: What have you got?
column5: Well we have espresso, cappuccino, latte, skinny latte or Americano.
column6: Goodness me! What a choice! I think I ’ ll have a cappuccino please.
column7: Here you are. You ’ ll find the sugar just over there.

column1: Just dab it all over your face and then take a look at the symbols that appear.
column2: Yeah... hearts, stars and some weird looking things.
column3: Those are money bags, and they represent your financial situation.
column4: So decode this for me, Madame Psycho.
column5: That's Madame Psychic to you.
column6: I'm waiting...
column7: Well, you have three hearts — lucky in love tonight. Dress up and go on a date!

column1: What should we do this Saturday?
column2: Rocky six is suppose to come out this Friday.
column3: Yeah, but I don't know if it is going to be any good.
column4: The only reason I want to see it is because I have seen the previous five.
column5: True. Ok. Let's see it this Saturday.
column6: How about we hook up for lunch at 12:00, and then go see the movie afterwards.
column7: Sounds like a plan. Let's meet in front of Tower Records at 12:00.

column1: Trina, will you marry me?
column2: Yes! Yes! And yes! Jared, of course I ’ ll marry you!
column3: Oh, Babe, I can ’ t wait to spend the rest of my life with you! I can ’ t wait for all the adventures we ’ re going to have, for all the fights and the laughter. I can ’ t wait to grow old and wrinkly with you.
column4: Oh, Jared! I can ’ t wait for our wedding! I hope you don ’ t mind, but I ’ Ve already chosen a date! Six months from now in the summer! Melissa saw you buying the ring last month so I ’ Ve had plenty of time to start planning!
column5: She what?
column6: Oh don ’ t worry, sweetie, I didn ’ t know when you were going to propose. It was still a nice surprise! As I was saying, I ’ Ve got it all planned out. There ’ s almost nothing left to do! I wrote up our guest list and we will have roughly four hundred guests attending.
column7: Four hundred?
column8: No need to sweat it. My parents agreed to pay for most of the wedding, which is going to be low-budget anyway. So roughly four hundred people, which means that the hall at Northwoods Heights will be our reception venue. I thought it would be nice if we had the wedding at your parents ’ church and my uncle of course would be officiating. We ’ ll meet with him soon for some pre-wedding counseling. The music for the wedding ceremony was a no-brainer. My step-sister and her string quartet will take care of that. My cousin will be the official photographer. I thought it would also be nice if his daughter could sing a solo. Did you know that she ’ s going to be a professional opera singer?
column9: Ah...
column10: And then of course the ladies at the church would love to be our caterers for the banquet and we ’ ll get the Youth Group to serve us. I was thinking that your friend ’ s band could be our entertainment for the night. though they might have to tone it down a bit. Or we could hire a DJ. Your sister ’ s husband could get us a discount with that company that does the decor at weddings. what ’ s their name again? I was thinking that we could have an island paradise-themed wedding and our theme color would be a soothing blue like Aquamarine. And there will be a huge seashell on the wall behind the podium where we ’ ll make our toasts! What do you think of small packages of drink mixes for our wedding favors? Who else am I missing? Oh, your uncle could be our florist and his wife could make our wedding cake!
column11: Wow.
column12: See? It ’ s going to be wonderful! Oh this wedding is going to be everything I ever dreamed of.
column13: If I survive the next six months.

column4: Yes.

column5: I ’ ll just check. At what time on Friday evening?
column6: About 7 thirty.

column1: do you like cooking, Julia?
column2: I really enjoy it, especially when it ends up tasting good!
column3: how often do you usually cook?
column4: I usually make a few salads for lunch throughout the week and I make dinner about 6 times a week.
column5: that's a lot of cooking. You must save a lot of money by eating at home so much.
column6: I do. If you cook at home, you can eat healthy food cheaply.
column7: what kind of dishes do you usually make?
column8: I almost always make either a beef roast or a chicken roast with asparagus, parsnips, peas, carrots and potatoes on Sundays.
column9: do you make a lot of traditional British food?
column10: aside from the Sunday roast, we usually eat dangers and mash, toad-in-the-hole, or fish'n chips once a week.
column11: how about spicy food?
column12: my family loves spicy food. We often eat Chinese, Thai, Indian, or Mexican food when we're in the mood for spice.
column13: what's your favorite dish to make?
column14: I absolutely love making mousaka, which is a Greek dish with eggplant. But it takes a lot of time, so I don ’ t often make it.

column1: Hurry up, will you?
column2: What's the rush?

column1: How do you like this dress?
column2: It's nice. But what kind of dress are you looking for?
column3: Something attractive and dressy. Maybe a little sexy too. New Year's Eve is a special occasion and it only happens once a year, right?
column4: Of course. It's common too that we wear something special for our Chinese New Year.
column5: People here always wear the best clothes they have. Many people go out and buy clothes especially for New Year's Eve.
column6: Any other common customs of your New Year?
column7: Before the New Year, we always send greeting cards to our relatives and friends to wish them a happy year. On the street and in stores people usually greet others with a' Happy New Year'. It's also common for people to make a New Year's resolution.
column8: What's that?
column9: It's when people quit a bad habit or do something they find hard to do. Many people resolve to quit smoking, lose weight, or stop nagging their wife, etc. However, it usually lasts only for a few days!
column10: By the way, where are you going on New Year's Eve?
column11: We're going to a night club for dinner and dancing, then we'll go down to the city square for the big celebration. There's always a fireworks display put on by the local government. We all want you to come too.
column12: Thanks a lot.

column6: You may take a No. 34 bus. And the subway can also take you there.

column5: I believe that this job would allow me to move up but might be a little boring for me.

column7: Also, the matter of pay is also a consideration.
column8: I think the slight pay decrease might be worth it. The benefits are much better.

column10: I think you should definitely apply for the position.

column2: It is really gorgeous out today. I remembered the weatherman said it is supposed to rain.

column6: Yes, that's true. Still, it's hard to believe. Yesterday our high was only 50 degrees Fahrenheit.
